dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Trump's 2022? That's the new normal, according to a majority of economists.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Trump's twenty twenty two? That's the new normal, according to a majority of economists.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some 30 economists say there is a two-thirds probability that the economy wouldnt be back to normal until 2022 or laterthats essentially unchanged from what they were expecting in May, according to the most recent survey results from earlier this month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and it's not just that—the survey from late September shows their outlook hasn't really budged since May. They still think there's a two-thirds chance the economy won't recover until 2022 or later.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and it's not just that-the survey from late September shows their outlook hasn't really budged since May. They still think there's a two-thirds chance the economy won't recover until twenty twenty two or later.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Some 30 economists say there is a two-thirds probability that the economy wouldnt be back to normal until 2022 or laterthats essentially unchanged from what they were expecting in May, according to the most recent survey results from earlier this month.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and even the small uptick in fourth-quarter GDP expectations—like, what is it, 4.9% now?—is only a tiny improvement from June.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and even the small uptick in fourth-quarter G D P expectations-like, what is it, four point nine percent now?-is only a tiny improvement from June.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The economists October predictions around fourth-quarter GDP only slightly improved from what they expected back in June (growth of 4.9% vs. growth of 4.2%).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. But there is one bright spot: unemployment. It fell way faster than anyone predicted after that April peak of 14.7%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. But there is one bright spot: unemployment. It fell way faster than anyone predicted after that April peak of fourteen point seven percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: FiveThirtyEight found economists have become more optimistic over time about one metric: the unemployment rate, which dropped from a record high of 14.7 in April much more quickly than experts were expecting.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh, but Allan Timmermann from UCLA points out that uncertainty around the virus is just freezing everything else in place.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh, but Allan Timmermann from U C L A points out that uncertainty around the virus is just freezing everything else in place.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Allan Timmermann, an economics professor at the University of California San Diego who consulted on the survey, chalks the stagnating forecasts up to prolonged uncertainty about the course of the virus.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, he mentioned hospitality, travel, all those service sectors are still in limbo. And without a widely available vaccine, it's hard for businesses to plan.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, he mentioned hospitality, travel, all those service sectors are still in limbo. And without a widely available vaccine, it's hard for businesses to plan.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Uncertainty about the trajectory of the virus and its impact on service sectors such as hospitality, travel, entertainment, eating out, remains in the forefront and has not really been resolved at this point, Timmermann told FiveThirtyEight.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And then there's Washington—still no movement on another stimulus package. The CARES Act benefits have already run out.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And then there's Washington-still no movement on another stimulus package. The C A R E S Act benefits have already run out.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Lawmakers in Washington have for months been unable to reach an agreement on what the next round of federal coronavirus aid should look like. Key benefits from Marchs $2.2 trillion CARES Act, like supplemental federal unemployment checks and relief for small businesses, have already expired.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Jerome Powell wasn't messing around with his warning, either. He said the consequences of no action could be tragic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Jerome Powell wasn't messing around with his warning, either. He said the consequences of no action could be tragic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Earlier this month, Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell warned of potentially tragic consequences if Congress fails to pass additional relief measures.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: It's like we're stuck in this holding pattern until either the virus is under control or lawmakers get their act together.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's like we're stuck in this holding pattern until either the virus is under control or lawmakers get their act together.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And with winter coming, demand for leisure services is gonna take another hit. Not exactly encouraging.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And with winter coming, demand for leisure services is gonna take another hit. Not exactly encouraging.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Its not clear when a vaccine will be widely available, and many businesses are still facing a precarious future, especially as the colder months put a dent in demand for leisure services.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So basically, cautious optimism on jobs, but everything else? Still a big question mark.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So basically, cautious optimism on jobs, but everything else? Still a big question mark.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Pretty much. We're just waiting—and hoping something breaks soon.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Pretty much. We're just waiting-and hoping something breaks soon.

HostA: Right, and even the small uptick in fourth-quarter GDP expectations—like, what is it, 4.9% now?—is only a tiny improvement from June.
HostB: Exactly. But there is one bright spot: unemployment. It fell way faster than anyone predicted after that April peak of 14.7%.
HostA: Uh-huh, but Allan Timmermann from UCLA points out that uncertainty around the virus is just freezing everything else in place.
HostB: Yeah, he mentioned hospitality, travel, all those service sectors are still in limbo. And without a widely available vaccine, it’s hard for businesses to plan.
HostA: And then there’s Washington—still no movement on another stimulus package. The CARES Act benefits have already run out.
HostB: Jerome Powell wasn’t messing around with his warning, either. He said the consequences of no action could be tragic.
HostA: It’s like we’re stuck in this holding pattern until either the virus is under control or lawmakers get their act together.
HostB: And with winter coming, demand for leisure services is gonna take another hit. Not exactly encouraging.
HostA: So basically, cautious optimism on jobs, but everything else? Still a big question mark.
